args:
Elysium, who has experienced the destruction
of many worlds, believes as the Progenitor does
that a world with choice is doomed. Since he
will not back down from this belief, a battle for
the very future of the world begins.
What is your game here, Elysium?\nWhy do you hinder Bahamut's return?
I seek to protect the world—and the\nhuman whelps within it.
How much time has passed since the\nProgenitor and the Origin departed\nand I took charge of this world?
In that time, possibility has split the\nsingle world into many.
I have seen millions upon millions of\nworlds, all of them ones in which the\nhumanoid whelps sought ＂possibility.＂

In one world, I saw them expulse the
dragons. Afterward, the waters dried,
the winds stilled, and the breath of life
ceased to pulse from the earth.
With nothing and no one left to turn to,\nthe humanoid races perished, cursing their\nown actions with their dying breaths.
Another world saw people who had seized\ncontrol of mana itself, allowing them to\ncreate rains and winds from nothing.
But a mistake of the most trivial nature\ncaused rains to fall without pause, and\nlife was soon swallowed by the sea.
Yet another world saw humanoids and\ndragons put aside all conflict and join\ntogether in the spirit of cooperation.

But in the end, they divided into groups
of their own and fell into conflict with
each another. Humans destroyed humans,
and dragons ended dragons.
Finally, I found a world in which conflict\nhad disappeared entirely—yet even there\ndid people continue to seek possibility.

As a result of their greed for a more
fulfilling life, they began to dabble in
black mana. The world was soon
enveloped in it, and vanished for all time.

I took manifold steps. In some cases,
I protected the humanoid whelps and
gave them my patronage, while in others
I pressed them into austerity.
Sometimes I managed their every move.\nSometimes I turned away altogether.

Yet the result of every conceivable
possibility being available to them was
ever the same: The world fell to ruin,
and the humanoid races vanished from it.
In how many worlds did I witness this?\nIs there even a word for such a number?
After seeing the same result again and\nagain, I realized a basic truth:
Possibility is no boon—it is poison.

Then you would approve of an existence
closed off by the Progenitor? You, who has
shouldered the duty of serving as
custodian of the world?
As custodian of the world, I must protect\nall that is within and of it.

So long as possibility exists, the human
whelps will never stop moving forward.
Yet a world of possibility offers only
oblivion as its endpoint.
In other words, though you are a dragon,\nyou deny the dragon Bahamut.
The Origin was mistaken. If he truly loved\nhis children, he should not have given\nthem possibility.
This is madness. If possibility is denied,\nwhat remains in the world?
Life. A world where humans and dragons\ndo not die out.
That may be life, but it is not living.\nYou speak of a world of prisoners.
There are no words that will avail you.\nYou have not known destruction as I have.
And I have no words left for one who\nwould merely look upon the world with\nresignation in their heart.
For the sake of this world, Holywyrm,\nI will see you gone from it.
It is I who will see you gone from it for the\nsame reason, pactbearer of Bahamut.
...Does this mean you plan to aid me\n{player_name}?
There's still so much I don't understand\nabout the world and your goals...
I don't even know for sure if helping you\nis the right thing to do.
Then stay out of my way and let me—
But I know this much: I don't want to live\nin a world devoid of possibility.
I'm not helping you. I'm just fighting to\nprotect my own possibility.
No matter what soul stands in my way,\nmy duty remains absolute.
My words are law. My body the world.\nAnd unto you, I bring judgment!
